Name: The Apollo Guidance Computer: Architecture and Operation (Springer Praxis Books / Space Exploration)

ReviewList.Text: This would be an excellent book to read after reading Charles Petzold's "Code", although the material is complete in itself.  While this is not a textbook, do not expect to simply passively read this, there are places where the reader will be well rewarded by breaking out pencil and paper and working through the explanations.  Core Rope memory in particualar is a tricky concept to work out, but exquisitely ingeniuos once the reader does savvy it.  Very nicely written and informative.

Simply outstanding reference for all Apollo era enthusiasts. I have many books and videos that chronical the history of Apollo and how we got to the Moon. I rate this among the best and most interesting.

I'm still reading this book months after I purchased it. The author is very very thorough with all of the  content. Its very deep - definitely not a quick read but with the importance of the topic, it shouldn't be. Its a great introduction to where computing has been and where it is going. Its amazing what NASA did with the technology of the day. This book makes a great gift for any NASA buff. It also makes a great history book too! I can't put this book down!

Info here that is nowhere else. Extremely detailed and if you are already literate in computer architecture there are some sections you'll want to skip over bit if not, you'll gain a high level knowledge of the workings of an embedded control computer and leave astounded at the creativity and ingenuity of the Apollo computer and also it's contribution to society by being the catalyst for technologies that gave us the cell phone, personal computer, and countless other life altering devices 20 years before we would have had them without the Apollo space programs forceful acceleration of the underlying digital technology. AMAZING!!

This book describes in excellent detail the problems and pitfalls of programming real-time applications in very limited computer hardware.  In brought back many memories of my days as an assembly language programmer working in the nuclear power industry during the same time period as the development of the AGC software.

Interesting and thorough description of the architecture and design tradeoffs to utilize the very limited memory and processor power available. A digit based user interface looking very primitive today, but did the job. Impressing !
It blows me away that they did so much with so little.  The cleaver machine language programmers are true magicians.  Wonderful book, much of it is over my head but I am still enjoying it!

I enjoyed the book.  The history of orbital mechanics, rendezvous and the guidance system were excellent reading.  The methods of how the limited memory were addressed were also very interesting.  However the details of the programing and memory manipulation were too tedious for me as I am not a programmer.  This ~25% of the book was more than I cared to read.
I am still working on this one. It's computer programming. I have a blast with this stuff, make sure you do as well. Good service
